edu.lehigh.cse.lol

Interface LolConfiguration


  • public interface LolConfiguration
    The LOLConfiguration interface describes some configuration details of the game

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      int getDefaultFontBlue()
      The blue component of the color of the default font
      java.lang.String getDefaultFontFace()
      When getting started, it's useful to use the "easy" versions of some methods, which rely on an implicit default font.
      int getDefaultFontGreen()
      The green component of the color of the default font
      int getDefaultFontRed()
      The red component of the color of the default font
      int getDefaultFontSize()
      The size of the default font
      java.lang.String getDefaultLoseText()
      When getting started, you may wish to use default text at the end of each level.
      java.lang.String getDefaultWinText()
      When getting started, you may wish to use default text at the end of each level.
      java.lang.String getGameTitle()
      When running on the desktop, this value will be used as the name on the window's title bar
      int getNumHelpScenes()
      The number of help levels in the game
      int getNumLevels()
      The number of levels in the game
      int getScreenHeight()
      The height of the screen of your device, in pixels.
      int getScreenWidth()
      The width of the screen of your device, in pixels.
      java.lang.String getStorageKey()
      To store "unlock" information, we need a unique identity for this game.
      boolean getUnlockMode()
      Is the game in "unlock mode"? In unlock mode, every level can be played.
      boolean getVibration()
      Is vibration support enabled?
      boolean showDebugBoxes()
      Is the game in "debug mode"? Debug mode includes drawing the frames-per-second on every level, drawing boxes around every touchable element, and drawing the raw shape for every entity in the game

    • Method Detail

      • getScreenWidth

        int getScreenWidth()
        The width of the screen of your device, in pixels. The actual value here isn't too important, the main point is that the ratio between this and height will determine how LOL scales your game.

      • getScreenHeight

        int getScreenHeight()
        The height of the screen of your device, in pixels.

      • getNumLevels

        int getNumLevels()
        The number of levels in the game

      • getNumHelpScenes

        int getNumHelpScenes()
        The number of help levels in the game

      • getVibration

        boolean getVibration()
        Is vibration support enabled?

      • getUnlockMode

        boolean getUnlockMode()
        Is the game in "unlock mode"? In unlock mode, every level can be played. When unlock mode is false, you can't play a level if you haven't already finished the preceding level.

      • showDebugBoxes

        boolean showDebugBoxes()
        Is the game in "debug mode"? Debug mode includes drawing the frames-per-second on every level, drawing boxes around every touchable element, and drawing the raw shape for every entity in the game

      • getStorageKey

        java.lang.String getStorageKey()
        To store "unlock" information, we need a unique identity for this game. It should probably be based on whatever you rename "com.me.mylolgame"

      • getDefaultFontFace

        java.lang.String getDefaultFontFace()
        When getting started, it's useful to use the "easy" versions of some methods, which rely on an implicit default font. You should provide the name of the font through this file, and be sure the font file (with a .ttf extension) is in your assets folder.

      • getDefaultFontSize

        int getDefaultFontSize()
        The size of the default font

      • getDefaultFontRed

        int getDefaultFontRed()
        The red component of the color of the default font

      • getDefaultFontGreen

        int getDefaultFontGreen()
        The green component of the color of the default font

      • getDefaultFontBlue

        int getDefaultFontBlue()
        The blue component of the color of the default font

      • getDefaultWinText

        java.lang.String getDefaultWinText()
        When getting started, you may wish to use default text at the end of each level. This is the default text when winning the level:

      • getDefaultLoseText

        java.lang.String getDefaultLoseText()
        When getting started, you may wish to use default text at the end of each level. This is the default text when losing the level:

      • getGameTitle

        java.lang.String getGameTitle()
        When running on the desktop, this value will be used as the name on the window's title bar
